Despite wishing otherwise, I believe there will be such an act. See: CSIS report and data (https://www.csis.org/analysis/military-police-and-rise-terrorism-united-states). In 2020, the number of domestic terrorist attacks and plots increased to its highest level since at least 1994, though fatalities were relatively low. Across all perpetrator ideologies, there were 110 domestic terrorist attacks and plots in 2020—an increase of 45 incidents since 2019 and 40 more incidents than in 2017, the year which previously had the most terrorist attacks and plots since the beginning of the data set. Despite this sharp increase in terrorist activity, the number of fatalities from domestic terrorist attacks was at its lowest level since 2013. Five people were killed in terrorist attacks in 2020—an 86 percent decrease from 2019, when 35 individuals died in terrorist attacks.

Passage of time. The news media are currently splashing headlines about a nut who was caught outside the US Capitol today, making this low-probability outcome salient in people's minds again. The odds of San Francisco having a 7.0 or higher earthquake is something like 3% a year. People who are considering moving there will tend to overweight the possibility of it happening in the next year. People who have lived in SF for awhile tend to underestimate it ("I've lived here for X years and everything has been fine!")
Active terrorist threat outside the Capitol today. Area being evacuated, ongoing active negotiation with suspect.

updating for time elapsed. I still like my base rate as well as any I've seen or thought of, and although the news makes it seem like things are getting crazier than normal, I don't think they are any crazier than when I made my initial forecast. I think it is important to realize that this is a two part question. 1) will an event occur that causes 10 or more fatalities before 1 Jan 2022 and 2) will that event be labeled domestic terrorism. Part 2 is tricky to forecast because terrorism is a political label for a specific type of crime, it's easier to predict a crime rate than to predict how policy makers will react to a specific criminal act.

Base rate from @hoosier2020 and @nadie708 is roughly 35%. That means the "daily" p ≈ 0.00117953097320931... There are 144 days until 2022-01-01, so we use 1 - (1 - p)^144 ≈ 15.6%. Crowd is 15%, so that's my base rate (3:17 as odds).

True domestic terrorism (accounting for an actual plan and motive) is unlikely. Mass shootings happen every single weekend in major cities around the country, though often with fewer than 10 deaths from a single event, and those aren't considered terrorism. The FBI's involvement in spurring on terroristic events has been in focus for the past 18+ years, up to and including current events. First in the case of local 'islamic terrorism' and now in this dubious branding shift to 'domestic/white' terrorism. Journalists have shown how nearly all the covered events involved FBI contact before, or just immediately prior via undercover assets. In numerous cases the person had a mental illness, was low IQ, or similar.

The Availability Heuristic is causing the Crowd to assign too high a probability: https://www.thecut.com/2017/01/why-americans-are-so-scared-of-terrorism.html >Americans are over 3,000 times more likely to be killed by a firearm than by terrorism. But the psychology is not so simple: Despite those stats, “terrorist attack on nation” and “victim of terrorism” both rank among the top five of Americans’ greatest fears, according to the 2016 edition of Chapman University’s Survey of American Fears.

This seems very hard to parse given the requirement under B of the Cornell link and the inherent subjectivity. If we go with, appearing on wikipedia page https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_terrorism#History_and_examples , then only 6 events qualify since 2000:

So it looked like this already happened in March 2021, but the motive didn't satisfy the definition of 'act of domestic terrorism' (motive was 'in response to Islamaphobic bullying', rather than ~'support for Al Qaeda'.). I'd say there is still a chance of later investigation concluding that it satisfies the technical definition of 'domestic terrorism' or of being prosecuted as such, which I'll estimate that as 5%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Boulder_shooting

In the last 10 years, there have been 4 attacks with greater than 10 fatalities, for a rate of 0.4 pa [1] (San Bernardino, Orlando, Pittsburgh, El Paso) There is 67% of the year left, multiplying 0.4 * 67% = 27% I don't have a compelling argument either way as to why the current environment is better of worse than the preceding 10 years, so no adjustment up or down

There may or may not be one. Base rate 50%. But the rise of domestic extremism acts are increasing. https://www.inquirer.com/news/nation-world/domestic-terrorism-analysis-study-far-right-20210412.html

Thinking about the issue from a different perspective, how hard is to kill 10 people at once (or nearly together)? Knives would be very difficult, as would handguns. The minimum might be automatic weapons (machine guns, bump stock rigged rifles), or explosives, but explosive are harder than it might seem (former Combat Engineer experience), and difficult to target. Automatic weapons are most likely if an individual intends such an event, but how easy is it to find (undetected) an automatic weapon, plus ammo and misc accoutrements. Bottom line, this is not easy to kill 10 people together.

Sadly the Georgia incident creates a possible segregation in our classifications. It's terrible, but it does not rise to Domestic Terrorism. These events may cause us to overestimate the probability of occurrence if emotions cloud the analysis. I'm going to try to stay data focus, the emotional side is so sad. Our threshold is 10 fatalities or more. Most of the attacks like Georgia seem to be less than our threshold (as near as I've been able to determine this morning). This isn't domestic terror. Its a national sickness.

At the risk of falling victim to recency bias, given yesterday's shootings in Georgia, I am significantly increasing my forecast. I accept the base rate others have cited of ±35%, and I am increasing the probability given the low state of social cohesion in the country after a year of pandemic, high and increasing political polarization, unified Democratic control of government, and the "Big Lie" that the 2020 election was stolen. I think, tragically, we will see more events targeted at minorities, we will also see a return to in-classroom education and unfortunately schools are a common target (although I would like clarification on whether a shooting at a school counts or not).

It seems the Georgia shooting an 16 March 2021 is a hate crime against Asian population, but so far "only" 8 fatalities are sadly to be reported. As several are still in hospitals and in unknown condition, this number could potentially rise. Being a fatal shooting and committed by a lone actor (as it seems investigators believe at the time of writing), it still could become categorized as an act of domestic terror, particularly if the one suspect under investigation and currently in custody proves to have had a political/anti-minority motive and motivation, imho. Closely watching the situation, however holding steady for now.

GOP political leaders have refused to stand for rule of law over raw partisanship. This has not only emboldened the violent faction within their own party, it has further radicalized those on the left who believe the system is too broken to ever work for them. Improving economic conditions and the waning of the covid pandemic might soothe tensions a lot but with fringe groups on both sides of the political spectrum feeling persecuted & that voting is hopeless the odds of violence are very high.
The strong right wing extremist faction in the U.S. has not disappeared, and we are all in danger.

Terrorism is different to a coup attempt.

For me, the storming of the Capitol Building wasn't an act of domestic terrorism, but a failed coup attempt. The primary aim was to keep Trump as President, not to strike terror into his opponents. Therefore, I think any threats to peace in the United States are more likely to be coup attempts rather than terrorist attempts.

Every month no event occurs, the probability should go down by ~.083, based on activity in political, Race, Religion, anti-government, Qanon and his minions, Corona induced pressure. i.e., who knows.

The base rate for acts of domestic terrorism in the US that resulted in 10 or more fatalities is approx 40%. (based on terrorist incidents between 2010-2020. Note: if we were to take a wider set of years, eg. the past 20 years, this would be MUCH lower).

Fewer 911 type attacks and more 'local' targets. Think less NYC and DC, but more Atlanta Olympics, Oklahoma, Vegas gunman etc. That suggests more possibilities. I'm not sure yet how to analyse that. The aim of domestic, specifically white nationalist, terrorism is generally not to cause the most fatalities as possible.

My prior is that there is an act of terrorism roughly every two years. Sometimes they double up. I am below 50% because I speculate that not having Trump in office will diminish the likelihood although I am not certain by how much.
Taking data (fatalities and number of attacks) from the last 47 years the likelihood could be very close to 22%, I'll make a forecast of 33% for the moment

Based on the Global Terrorism Database (GTD) for the US from 2001 (immediately after 9/11) to December 2018 we see 496 terrorist attacks. The mean number of fatalities is 0.73, primarily because 407 (82%) of the attacks had no fatalities. Excluding those, we have a mean of 4.07 fatalities with 9 out of 89 attacks (10%) including 10 or more fatalities. 9 out of 363 is 2.47% attacks with more than 10 fatalities.
If you count school shootings and the like,, yes.

Given the number of "Domestic" terror events in the history of the US there have been in total, and how many of the had more than 10 Fatalities, the qty is rather small over a large time period. Given the high rates of domestic terrorism and the harsh political and social climates following the Capitol insurrection and individual state rallies, I believe that it is probable to have 10 or greater casualties before 2022.

We have had two of these in the last three years, and potentially more if some perpetrators got luckier or if the definition were a little looser. Given the long timeline, this event seems very probable. However, I will note that most recent domestic terrorist incidents were partly due to the political atmosphere nurtured by the previous administration. Given that Biden is cracking down it would make sense to see a reduction. We will need to see how his policies play out.
Not by Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus. Left hand right hand.

It occurs to me me that most if not all of the events we are using as baseline all occur within a context of relative calm, and the authorities were NOT on alert. Our time frame is less than a year, and the authorities are not likely to have completely dropped their guard. I think a low probability at this point is appropriate, with increasing probability to about the baseline around 15%.

All my base rate data comes from wikipedia at this point and I have not verified that all of the domestic terrorism incidents they count actually meet the legal criteria as defined in this question. however: since 1900 there have been 181 domestic terror incidents 17 with 10+ fatalities so that is about 1.5 incidents a year, since 10% of incidents have 10+ fatalities that is about at 14% chance that there will be an incident in any given year that has 10+ fatalities.
It's pretty obvious even after only two days that nobody can agree on what constitutes "domestic terrorism" or even "domestic" or "terrorism."

The question ignores incidents like the Mandalay Bay shooter, the dude who blew himself up outside of an AT&T communication hub in Dec, and the Times Square car bomber in 2019. Either these were not labeled as "domestic terrorism", or "10 or more deaths" did not occur. We misclassify and deflect at our collective peril. It's more important to watch the trend in the frequency of such acts rather than the severity of the outcomes. I can't yet find evidence with definitional consistency that supports my contention that such acts are occurring, at at a higher frequency than "before". I'll just say, qualitatively - there's a lot of "hateration" out there. And it's indiscriminate - the equivalent of swinging one's arms wildly while waiting for the train---somebody's going to get hit in the schnozz at some point. So too here - only a matter of time before the question's thresholds are met. On this, I'd very much like to be 100% wrong in 2021.

Interesting question. I assume the perpetrator(s) must actually identify their motive, or a pattern of behavior that can be construed as constituting a motive (as in the El Paso, or Oklahoma City, or Pittsburgh massacres). However, I note that the Cornell definition is:

Since 2000 there have been 7 acts of domestic terrorism that have resulted in 10 or more fatalities. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrorism_in_the_United_States#2020%E2%80%93present) This gives me a base rate of 35% for the chance that there will be an act of domestic terrorism in the United States resulting in 10 or more fatalities in a given year. I will reduce this by 3% (roughly 1/12) since the month of January has already passed so I am now at 32%. I will reduce the forecast by another 5% to 27% due to some places of worship, restaurants, and nightclubs, which are frequent targets for acts of domestic terrorism, being closed for COVID-19. The heightened level of security in the United States likely makes it more difficult to plan and carry out an attack so I will further reduce my forecast by 8% to 19%. Lastly, I will slight increase my forecast by 3% given the increased chance of a domestic terrorist attack by a white supremacist group for a final forecast of 22%.
